Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Guys excuse my haste and ignorance but after realising BLOCK ain't something I'm gonna be able to test right now without an all nighter basically

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I've moved on straight to BarterDEX and now that I've downloaded it I'm immediately confronted with a form for a "Passphrase", "Net ID", and "Seed Node IP"

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I suppose I can guess what those are but have I skipped over some obvious instructions?

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Or are newcomers expected to then go and Google these things to find out what the hell they are?

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I mean "DOWNLOAD BARTERDEX" is right there on the front page with no indication that there's any significant literature to go through

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: And yet a quick glance at what I've just downloaded tells me that this one is going to have to wait till tomorrow also

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> Passphrase is to access your wallet address.  Netid are like channels there are  over 14000 of them.  And seed node is a node that you connect with directly to receive the p2p data.

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: It says "Goal Now" in the middle of it with separate lines lols what??

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> That's if you want to set a portfolio and track it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> It's probably best for you to watch a tutorial video

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> https://youtu.be/sA_1H6oAT_E

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Apologies to be one of those annoying dicks but yeah maybe you want to shove a link for that on the homepage or something heh

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: It's suddenly making a great deal of sense to me why so many traders are flocking to dexsthat can be used within seconds like Bitshares

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I'm not saying that's a good thing or anything but yeah it makes a lot of sense now

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> Different applications

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I'm basically looking to weigh BLOCK and WAVES and KMD against each other

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: To see which one is really closest to proper decentralisation

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: But it's difficult when literally all you can find is shill articles

Content: Pros are documented everywhere but cons... Not really

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Bitshares's main con obviously being the damn gateways

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I'll check this vid but I have a couple of other quick questions if you're still about heh bot that appears to be a human

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> Hyperdex is a 3rd party version that is easier to use.  The cons to atomic swap DEX is confirmation time dependent for completing trade steps.   There is a 0confirm mode but it's experimental.  Soon you will be able to create a waves or bitshares like exchange on a Komodo assetchain.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [matrix] <polycryptoblog:matrix.org> Sure ask away

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Right yeah heh that's kinda what I expected although I didn't realise the latter was apparently expected to become a reality so soon

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: When BarterDEX achieves all of its ambitions what will be the remaining drawbacks / tradeoffs versus a centralised exchange by then?

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: And my other question is whether it's decentralised or **decentralised**

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: IE is it still a rubber stamp or is it every bit as indestructible as say Bitcoin is already?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: BarterDEX operates on a true p2p protocol,  it allows for multi channel trading ,  uses native coins which never leave your control until trade is complete .  Blocknet uses masternodes to do their order books ,  which by definition is a subset of nodes.  Every LP makes orderbooks .  Waves and Bitshares use proxy tokens ,  which means you give up control of your coins .

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: You have to understand Atomic Swap DEX is not a competitor for centralized exchanges.  It's just for certain types of transactions it is a better tool to use

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: I know most of the basic fundamentals heh I mean so far what I understand of the dexs with which I'm less familiar is that say BTS and WAVES have decentralisation issues that allows them to compete with centralised exchanges whilst BLOCK and KMD are really only suitable for big trades rather than lunch money but at the same time are properly decentralised on account of that (correct me if I have any of that arse about face of course)

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Bts and waves can't compete with centralized exchanges,  that's just hype

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: By virtue of the fact that they're P2P / on-chain as opposed to gateway oriented

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Why do you say that about Waves? Legit question heh I hear rumblings of it having problems but I've never seen anybody properly articulate what they are

Author: Shingo Murata#3184
Content: Bitshares's flaws I'm much more familiar with

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Confirmation times on trades

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Even though faster than atomic swap
